But I suppose that must be Marian Keyes' great talent as a writer, that she can write about the same family from two points of view and make them seem entirely different.Almost 5-star!

This is a book I randomly picked up during a Sunday sale in the streets of Nairobi.I do not remember why I picked it up, seeing as I had never heard of the author. But I am so glad that I picked it up. I still have the book; a valuable part of my book collection. The book is very engaging, it had me laughing and almost crying. It was a definite page turner and still my favourite book by Marian Keyes and definitely my favourite from the Walsh Family series.I liked Anna's POV, in the state of mind of a person grieving; trying to come to terms with it. I like that the process was not sugar coated, it felt like it could actually happen.The ending was amazing! I like that there was a bit of mystery about it, even though I am certain that anyone who has read the book had picked a side in the choice that Anna was to make, if at all she wanted to make it. I also appreciate the sense of hope that Marian Keyes gives to others going through such an experience. That is all I can say without spoiling the book for those considering reading it.

I enjoyed the book, which was no surprise since I like everything I've read by the author. She has this wonderful gift about creating a story out of a very distressing situation, and making that story hilarious, marvelously entertaining, and compulsively readable while still being true to the human condition -- showing the full range of difficult emotions that characters are going through and handling tough subjects with sensitivity.Favorite quotes:"I stared at the little piece of machinery: phones have always seemed magical to me, the way they pull off the unlikeliest, most geographically distant connections. I know there are perfectly good explanations of how it all works, but I've never stopped being amazed at the wondrousness of people on opposite sides of oceans being able to talk to each other." p.29"Swirling, whirling past their radiant faces, I remembered something I hadn't known I'd forgotten: Aidan wasn't the only person I loved; I loved other people, too. I loved my sisters, I loved my mother, I loved my dad, I loved my nieces, I loved my nephews, I loved Jacqui. At that moment I loved everybody." p.429

Anybody Out There? is Marian Keyes at her absolute best. I love her books about the Walsh family, starring 5 Irish sisters and their parents, as they bumble along in life. This particular novel follows the second youngest, Anna, whose been seen in the previous novels as being flakey, scatterbrained and spiritual in a faux-hippie type of way. The novel opens with her recovering from an accident that led to incredible physical pain and her denial that her husband of less than a year is dead. The novel proceeds, in the most heartbreaking vein, to follow her as she works through the cycle of grief. I wasn’t expecting the twist towards the latter half of the novel which as a reader, is always enjoyable! What I loved most about this novel was how clearly Anna’s voice shown through. I physically felt her grief, her desperation, her anger, her sadness and her devastation. This was a fitting conclusion to the Walsh series.

Anna, Irish ex-pat, works for a cosmetics company in NY where she falls for Aiden. After recuperating with her family in Ireland, she heads back to NY to find him. I enjoyed so much about this delightful story, the “Irishness” of the humour and expressions were heartwarming and great fun - the book was two thirds hilariously entertaining and one third incredibly moving. The story jumps back and forth in time and we aren’t privy to the reason Anna is recuperating until about half way through - I kept thinking I must have skipped some pages, but there’s a good reason for the slow reveals. As I’ve found with other Marian Keyes books, the resolutions are realistically slow and hard won, rather than quick. It’s a book I’d like to return to again and again. 🎧 I must seek out more narrations by Caroline Lennon, her Irish accent was pure joy, her comic timing was perfect, and all the Irish and American characters worked brilliantly.

At last, my final Keyes with a final review. Why split a continuing plot into three parts, why?! By the time the "big reveal" appears of how Anna sustained her injuries, you pretty much know what went down. And again so many unnecessary sub-characters that somehow get a mention in the epilogue. And Mitch seems like he'll become this important element in Anna's life, but no, he just kind of slinks away. And Janie, whatta piece of work she must've been before Anna came into Aidan's life, geez. Oh yeah, she just casually keeps seeing, sorry, sleeping with her ex whilst dating another guy who ends up being her future husband, what?! And the whole dog poo thing, seriously?! What a useless addition to an already mediocre plot. Once again, a book that should've been cut down to less than 300 pages. But happy to say, this is the last Keyes that I will ever read. Ever.

It's been a while since I read a Marian Keyes book so I didn't connect this one with Watermelon, however although it's about the same family this is Anna's story and can easily be read as a stand alone.It's chick lit at its best. Funny in places, sad in places but (mainly) credible. At the start of the story Anna is recuperating at her family home in Ireland after an accident. We don't immediately learn much about this accident or where her husband is. We don't even know Aiden is her husband. We're drip fed information and initially I wasn't sure I was going to be drawn in enough to keep me interested considering it's a long book - 592 pages. I wondered where it was going and then there's a revelation and I was hooked. Judging by the reviews you'll either love it or hate it but it's not a fluffy romantic read and I enjoyed it.

I liked the story BUT I have to qualify that with some strong criticism. Verbal diarrhoea: The book is almost 600 pages when 400 would have been plenty. There is so much filler , including a whole chunk of boring emails into an unrelated side story. The overall book is unwieldy with so many named characters and descriptions and forays into their lives.Tediously quirky: Yes, it is witty and clever, but it wears thin and detracts from the serious passages.Lack of focus: See above. There's a lot of wading through mud just to get to the main story.This is the third Marian Keyes book I've read, and it will be the last. The author (who I have heard on podcasts) does not know how to edit or hone a story down to the gems. Instead every single thought that goes through her head is spewed straight onto the page. It's time for a diet.

This is my second Marian Keyes this year. I find her writing utterly compelling and believable. Again, I'd say the tragicomedy genre I'm enjoying so much is growing, as I'd put this novel into that category.Anna has hit rock bottom and despite her large Irish family rallying around her, she just wants to be alone. Without giving anything away, I can relate to Anna's desperation and heartache and the impossible pain and having to drag your bum through another day that you can't bear to face. Throwing herself (and myself) into work. And mixed with the tragedy, there's the beautiful humour and the goings on of everyday life, as irritating as that is when you become obsessed with trying to get to the bottom of something and ordinary life is so tiresome and continuous.I think it's brilliant writing!

This woman sure can write. Witty dialogs, good plot, great humour and vivid descriptions. Very lively. But all this for THAT? Nearly 600 pages for what? Could have done it in 300 and it would have been a great book.First part fine! We get into the plot (rather well driven) and the charaters'psychology.Humour catches on.We get into it. Preparing for a nice journey.Second part is such a bore! Endless, repetitive, humour nearly gone? I flipped through the pages searching for a place where to land. Knew what would come next.Third part is a slow recovery. Back to the plot in a hurry to be finished with it.Maybe I didn't get it, maybeMy mistake But 600 pages for heaven's sake! (So to speak)

I really enjoyed this! For me, Angels was not as good as its predecessors - unless it's just that Maggie isn't my favourite Walsh sister - but this book seemed to recapture all of the magic and bitter-sweet life moments of Watermelon and Rachel's Holiday. Anna, from her own point of view, is not who I had expected and I felt a deep sympathy with her character. If her obstinate desire to achieve the impossible seemed a bit annoying, I needed to remind myself that each person has different coping mechanisms and these take time to work through. The narration was also excellent, and despite being a new voice in the series, Caroline Lennon captures Anna well and was an inspired choice for her story. A well-deserved 5 stars.

This book entered my life at the exact right time. Reading has been going slow for me in the past few weeks. I've really missed the feeling of a book pulling me in to it's world. So THANK YOU Marian Keyes!!Even with all the sorrow and heartbreak and hysteric pursuits of that which was lost, Marian Keyes managed to make it a heart warming and light book. I loved it, and in my opinion this book is a very good place to start if you haven't read in a while and wish to pick it back up. Although it is a bit long, the pages just fly by and before you know it you're experiencing that all-to-familiar feeling of nostalgy that comes with saying goodbye to the world you got to live in on borrowed time.

Definitely my 2nd favorite in the Walsh family series. It was absolutely heartbreaking and I avoid reading spoilers so once I reached Anna's realization I burst into tears. It was interesting to see how Anna's character developed from the young, aloof Walsh sister to a woman suffering an enormous tragedy. For such a heavy book, my favorite moments were Helen's hilarious emails to Anna detailing her escapades as a Private Detective. Anybody Out There is a powerful book about love and loss and it was hard to read at times but I was satisfied with the outcome. I also like how the love interest is left ambiguous and was thrilled to have some clarity in Helen's novel Mercy Close because I did not actually guess the correct love interest! Great book.

This book is classified as chick lit. It is not! Although it's well written and the author has great ability at conveying strong emotions, it's not the type of book I enjoy reading. When I started it, I was curious about what happened to the heroine, once I knew, I was so desperate to know what happened to her husband and instead, it kept dragging on and on about inconsequential things, until finally we get to know the tragic events that took place. It made me cry and so sad, I couldn't get past the part where she seeks the help of a psychic. I personally don't believe in that crap, so I gave up on the book.

Anna Walsh is officially a wreck. Physically broken and emotionally shattered, she lies on her parents' Dublin sofa with only one thing on her mind: getting back to New York. New York means her best friends, The Most Fabulous Job In The World™ and above all, it means her husband, Aidan.But nothing in Anna's life is that simple anymore... Not only is her return to Manhattan complicated by her physical and emotional scars – but Aidan seems to have vanished. Is it time for Anna to move on? Is it even possible for her to move on? A motley group of misfits, an earth-shattering revelation, two births and one very weird wedding might help Anna find some answers – and change her life forever

I can see how the beginning of the book could annoy some impatient readers- and I admit I was one of them! Anna has extensive injuries from an unknown event but believe me, just wait until you find out! In my copy, it was about 1/5 of the way through the book. Many other reviewers talk about how emotional they were while reading but I found it rather peaceful, actually. As always, Marian's development of the characters creates a bond between the reader and the character, something a truly love about her writing style. I'd recommend reading this book in order of the Walsh Family books to help better develop that bond with the character.

So I can't really muster up a lot of feelings for this book. I didn't even have a lot of feelings while reading it. But the one thing I have to say is that it kept me mildly interested. The writing wasn't bad and despite the length of the book it flowed well. The plot was good but it lacked impact in all categories. From the accident, acceptance, grief, sub-plots, without giving anything away it was all just okay. I found nothing to be remotely exciting or that kept me on tenterhooks for more. But it was reasonably okay too. I'm tired of bad writings and bad executions of plots so this fit in well in that regard.Pisss: Aidan was a sweetheart.

I really liked it. People have reviewed on here that they didn’t like the plot twist of finding out that Aidan was dead. I don’t actually think it was meant to be a twist at all. I think it was written that way because Anna couldn’t admit to herself that he’d gone. The whole story was her finding her way through her grief, something which rang true for me. I like how the Walsh stories link but can be read in their own. Marian Keyes has an engaging way of writing, I’m not into make up or the kind of world that Anna lives in but I still found myself really wanting her to do well in her pitch for Formula 12. Worth a read. You might need a tissue though.

I love this author so I have read a ton of her books. This was the last book in the series of the Walsh family that I had to read. I read them out of order which is not a big deal since the author fills you in on what happened and recaps everything. This Irish family is great and very entertaining. She packs a lot in her books and they are long but it doesn't feel like she fills them with a lot of description, she just packs a lot into her books. This was yet another book that was super enjoyable to read as you can see it was almost 500 pages that I finished in 4 days. Highly recommend this book and all of her books especially this series!

I'm probably usually bias when it comes to Marian Keyes but I completely enjoyed this book. It wasn't what I'd expected but was so relatable. Grief, grief is something else... I cried my eyes out part 2 moving forward and it was so unexpected. 200 pages in moving forward I expected a happily ever after, a fairytale for Anna but it didn't happen as expected. I cried with her, felt her pain. Her heartache. Grief is something else 💔Mum Walsh and Helen were my fave... Completely enjoyed the email exchanges. The Mr Big case 😅 felt like a soap opera, something made up. I love Marian Keyes, enjoyed this book ❤️📚

I think I probably read this about 15 years ago, but re-listening to the audiobook was a joy. Marian Keyes shows why she is the queen of warm and funny women's fiction. I loved her and secretly wanted to be Irish ever since I read Lucy Sullivan is Getting Married as an impressionable 12 year old. I love how she cloaks serious subjects with a deft touch. The only slightly weird thing is the character Anna in this book bears very little resemblance to how she's portrayed in the other sister's books (how do I remember that, I read them in the early 2000s). Still a cracking story.Now I want to listen to all her books being read in a lovely Irish accent.

This is the 4th book in Walsh sisters series by Marian Keyes and of course I loved it. This is Anna Walsh's story and like the other books in this series the story of this Irish family and all their comings and goings is both hilarious and sometimes deeply sad.This book has a little bit of a twist to it that I caught onto pretty early on in the story but that didn't take away from the story.This book deals with death, some addictive behavior, infidelity, but most of all it is a story of love and how it appears in so many forms in each of our lives each day.I loved the book.

This was by far the best of the series so far.Anna is the most likeable of all the sisters so far. She is easy to identify with and her relationship with Aidan felt like the most realistic of all the romances so far. Her interactions with her sisters were great and it was nice for Rachel and Luke to play quite a big part in the story.The main weakness was definitely the side story of Helen and her private detective investigations. Although it added a bit of light relief if it had been stripped out the book would have been so much more effective.A really great and poignant book.

I found this book in a charity shop and as I have not read any by this author I thought I would give it a go. I did not realise it was book four of this zany Irish family. I started reading in my lunch time before I realised what was going on. Heart breaking half way through I did shed quite a few tears. This is a beautiful written book on grief and loss. The harsh reality that life goes on for everyone around you whilst life stands still for our main character. Sad and funny this book is a rollercoaster of emotions.

Overall, the ratings were quite good and I read one of the reviews which said it was a 'pageturner' so out of curiosity I started reading it. Boom! Yeah it really was a pageturner. I agree. It was beyond my imagination putting myself in the protagonist's shoes though I would say this book taught me a life lesson. I didn't expect this book to be that thick so I wondered how long it'll take for me to finish it however now is the best time being absorbed in reading, and I suppose this book made me realise that.

Ohhhhhh there’s so much I wanted to love about this book. It started off really engaging and endearing. And then it lost me with all the medium/psychic exploration. BUT, Anna’s grief and denial were palpable so the medium stuff was understandable, but not my thing. There were too many characters to keep up with (maybe I would have been familiar had I read the previous books?). A lot going on with the sisters and really too many subplots. There were some laugh out loud and fun moment, but overall too much going on.

I really wanted to like this book because I grew fond of Anna in the previous book in the series 'Angels'. The first part of the story I initially enjoyed a great deal. Possibly because we were reinitroduced to the sisters from the first three books. Unlike others, I never guessed why Aiden didnt call Anna and never suspected the real reason. But by part two we all know why Aiden has not replied and this took the shine off part one for me because I found it so inplausible. I found part two so slow and tedious that I just could not be bothered to finish it.

Another enjoyable Marian Keyes book. I had not read any of the Walsh Family series and still found the book easy to follow. Some of the same County Clare characters with New Yorkers as well. Great to see Knockavoy still got a mention. Took me until half way through the book before I knew what the title really meant. I had thought that her husband had left her mysteriously - until then and that she had been attacked. I found the print size a bit of a challenge as it was so large. The book was quick to read though.

I cried a couple of times reading this book. Anna's angst every time she realised Aidan was dead really resonated with me. I mourned his death with her, felt her anger at Janie and Aidan and Aidan's mother Dianne and understood why she didn't want to speak to Kevin. I adored that she excelled at work and used her dealing with Aidan's death to (albeit unknowingly) better herself. She deserved the Forumla 12 account! She was incredible! I also loved that despite her pain, she supported Jaqui and thought the ending was super realistic but special.

This book started out great, really had my attention....then I began to notice that each day for the main character was like groundhog day and I began to lose interest in her story. What really did me in were the e-mails she was receiving from her mother and sister(s) and I found myself asking "why?" I realize that this is book #4 in the Walsh Family, maybe if I had read the first 3 I might have enjoyed it more. I can't see myself reading those other books, unfortunately the Walsh Family just doesn't hold my attention. I would recommend to others that they start reading at #1.

I liked the sample so i bought the book on sale. By reading reviews, i got to know that there is interesting twist around page 200. Although i had started losing interest by page 150 but kept going because of interest in twist. But when i got to know the twist , it was not good enough for my interest. After reading some more pages, i am getting bored now after page 300 so leaving it.I should have guessed the twist by book's name or some more reviews. My bad :(

This book resonated so hard with me I had a tough time in some bits - where she describes the grief and the shock. She's humorous, her vernacular is great to read, the warmth in her characters comes through and you want to know more about the characters - she leaves you wanting more.The story with her mum warring with the woman with the poopy dog, her sister and her brush with the Mafia, and her own story with the cosmetic PR, all of these make for a delightful read.

Wow. What an emotional roller-coaster. Hilariously funny and heart breakingly sad. There were moments where I literally laughed out loud and other moments where I had tears in my eyes. I loved the Walsh family, particularly mum and Helen. Have loved Marian Keyes for a while but will definitely be on the look out for her books in the future. Would definitely recommend to anyone looking for an emotional roller-coaster. 9/10

I did not expect anything from this book, but it turned out to be a compelling read. It is written in easy-to-read style. At first, what kept me going was a curiosity as to what actually happened to Anna. As it progressed, it got deeper than that. I don't want to spoil anything so I'll leave it just that. It consists of mixture of humor, sweet love, sadness, despair, grief, success, just everything we find in daily life, each with the right portion.

These days my thoughts wander and transform into scenarios involving my own life when I read novels, so naturally I wept a lot reading this because I imagined what it would be like for me, if what happened to Anna, happened to me. That is also why it took me such a long time to finish it - I could not bring myself to continue reading after the first 180 pages or so because it hurt too much. I picked it up again yesterday, and it feels good to have finished it today.

I started out loving this book but quickly tired of the manic circumstantial detail obscuring every movement of the story... So many love Marian Keyes books, and I think she is a very loveable person, having heard her in an interview. I may go back to this one day, but had to abandon it because it was too slow, too enigmatic, too "teasing" of things-t0-come... Sorry. I will try to read another title because she is so popular.

I enjoyed this! It took me a while to properly get into it but In the end I enjoyed the story. The twist took me completely by surprise and changed the entire tone of the book. Definitely a product of the early 2000’s but still relevant enough for me to keep reading. When I first started, I didn’t think I would finish it, but now I’m thinking I’d like to read more about these crazy Walshes and see what else Marian Keyes has to offer

Very interesting - different than I usually read. The plot has quite surprising twists and the author is quite often burst-out-laughing hilarious. Though it is 593 pages, I flew through it because it's so interesting. The character descriptions are amazing and the plot sucks you right in. The off-colour language and mindset was at certain times disturbing, but over-all, I'm glad I read it. It is a brilliant education as we walk Anna's journey with her.

While this was a great book, it just felt a little drawn out. There are five daughters in the Walsh family. This book focuses on Anna, but includes all the sisters and their current situations (which may be partly why the book is so long). Anna spends weeks recovering in her family home in Ireland; she then returns to her highly demanding job in NYC where she is forced to come to terms with recent events in her life.

Follows Anna’s journey in the first year after her husband dies. For the first half of the book, since Anna doesn’t admit it, you don’t know it either. You think that he’s left her. Some insightful thoughts:- remember that the world is still full of people you love. - you don’t truly start to heal until you’ve lived a year and a day without them. - it’s not a life interrupted. It’s a life completed. - their life has ended. Yours has not.

Chick lit with a twist. The thing about chick lit is that no issue is so bad it can’t be overcome in 350 pages or a year in the life of the characters. It is escape literature of the highest order. This held my interest. In writing this review, months after finishing the book I’ve forgotten much of the book. Nevertheless I remember being entertained. And I also found myself mixing Walsh up with Keyes. The conclusion: Now I have two authors to look for when I want reliable chick lit.

This book felt like a warm mug of coffee in your hands. It was a beautiful tale of grief, of how life moves on even when you don't want it to. I like that Keyes managed to avoid the usual cliches of grief or have Anna find relief in someone else, in the end she found it in herself. There was such a natural progression through the stages of grieving someone and it is a book I shall definitely return to once I've finally stopped crying.

I just can´t believe all the things that happen to the Walsh girls. Is life really like that? Unpredictable, tragic, surprising and full of consequences? I guess it is, it may sound incredible, but every situation seems possible, and I sure there are a lot of families that at least have one of the problems that happen to them. Surprisingly, this is a nice collection of warm and really funny books. Kudos to Marian Keyes.

I picked this up on what started to be a quiet night shift, somebody had left it in the tea room (we have take a book, leave a book thing going on) and I thought ahh it looks quite long for me, but I got through it really quick (for me) as I couldn’t put it down. I got lost a couple of times with all the characters but probably doesn’t help I haven’t read the other books about the Walsh family. Overall enjoyed it

When I picked this up, I wasn't actually aware that it was part of the same series as Rachel's Holiday, but I was thrilled to find that out! I love Keyes' books, they are charming, heartfelt, and deal with serious topics (beyond the usual rom-com stuff) that many books in the same style would avoid. The book has one big 'twist' - and it's something that is fairly easy to guess before it is revealed, but isn't obvious from the very start, which is actually quite satisfying!

Yup, I'm only giving it two stars for the great sense of humor the author has. I laughed out loud while reading which is something I don't usually do!But, this book is a mess! (as a lot of reviewers said).I skipped most of part two. And the emails! It just adds unnecessary pages to the book. It took a lot of time to finish it since it's 420 pages long but there's no freaking story :)

Disappointing. Sad.I keep coming back to MK because I loved Sushi for Beginners, and Lucy Sullivan, but some of the others have been boring and disappointing and I haven't liked the characters or the supernatural fantasy themes. I'm hoping she'll bring out another one that I'll like, because when they're good, they're very good. But that's just my opinion...

I normally love Marian Keyes books. I first started reading them when I was a teen. I fell in love with her style of writing and her books. However I just couldn’t get into this book. It took to long to know what happened to Her partner. I gave it a good shot got up to 255 but I couldn’t go further.

I had forgotten how much I love Marion Keyes. What a great book this was, a study of grief that was both poignant and funny at the same time and spot on. I loved how I never guessed what was going to happen at any point in the story and enjoyed all the email exchanges. I read this on holiday and sped through it. Brilliant.

The Walsh sisters....& Mum...are back! This is Anna's tale & although it doesn't take long to work out what has happened to Aiden, it's a while before your suspicions are actually confirmed. It's funny (I found the emails from Helen especially amusing), it's heart warming & it's sad - a great book - just what I've come to expect from this author.

Keyes did a wonderful job conveying the desperate grief of Anna. I rooted for her the entire (lengthy) book. The secondary stories of Anna's mother and sister kept the book from being too depressing. [Anna's mother's emails to Anna were a riot.] I was a little disappointed by the very, very end ... eye rolling stuff, in my opinion. But, overall, an enjoyable chick lit read with some heft.

I don’t have a whole lot to say about this one. It was a decent, easy read about moving forward after tragedy and the stages of grieving. There didn’t seem to be any deep hidden messages which is typical of this type of book. Surprisingly for a book about death it was light and had an upbeat feel to it. Another easy read to add to my list.

I forgot how much I love Marian Keyes. The Walshes - the crazy family who stick by each other and supply us with endless laughs. I’ve read all the previous books years ago and it all came back to me. I’m looking forward to the last daughters story (Helen the private investigator). Where this was a poignant story with a side order of funny, I’m sure the next one will be hilarious.

This series just gets better and better. I'm amazed by Keyes' ability to weave a story that is hilarious, rolling on the floor one minute and poignant, between the eyes truth/real life that has me bawling my eyes out the next. 4 out of 5 books in, and my amazement hasn't worn off. Book 5 is on order. This series is a chick lit Must Read.

A MUST read. Although I loved this book (and I was given it) I didn’t realise until near the end that it’s part of a three book series - I’ll be buying the others. This one will have you crying then laughing then crying again. I’ll be reading more by this author.And YES it was a real life paper (with lots of pages) book - you know, one of the old fashioned things that sit on a shelf!!!

Emotional rollercoaster of a book. Sad, touching, heartwarming, everything all in one. I’ve laughed and cried at this book. Loved the style of writing and felt as if the author was talking to me and the characters wereVery vividly depicted and I loved them all. Ended in tears but happy tears. Very very lovely book

I always found Anna and Helen the more interesting of the sisters , although Rachel’s Holiday is still my favourite of the series. Very good plot although the ‘twist’ (can we even call it that) at the beginning was predictable , the one in part 3 was much more of a surprise. Very emotional reading .

Anna was always my favourite of the Walsh family, so I was super excited when I saw there was an ‘Anna’ book. Regarding the reveal half-way through, I knew something was coming. I didn’t expect it to be what it was and started crying on a packed tube on my way to work. It was just so simply revealed.

Truth: when I found out about Aidan, I couldn't even touch the book for nearly a week. It was an awful thing to do after having us fall in love with the character. I get it, it made the book so much more compelling but I cursed the author a lot in that week. But being able to feel every moment with Anna was a wonderful journey and the ending couldn't be more lovely.

I read this about 8 years ago and have read it at least once a year since. I adore this story. Emotionally I've never been so broken - this is a story that takes your heart in it's hands, pummels it and then slowly massages it back to health. I don't want to leave spoilers. I just want to say, please read this.

For me, this was Ms. Keyes best one yet! I just love the trials and tales of the Walsh sisters. Quite honestly, this would have gotten a 5, but for a weird twist. Having said that, Ms. Keyes basically kept the drama going for the main story and several subplots – all a hoot considering the novels serious subject. Consider me a Fan Boy of M.s Keyes.

Didn't realize this was part of a series! I picked this up in a coffee shop book exchange expecting something light hearted, funny, and quirky. Even though this is a novel about death & despair, it still managed to be all 3 of those things! Marian had me laughing out loud at several parts, and tied it up nicely in the end. Not dying to read the rest of this series though.

I read this book many years ago and liked this and all the other Walsh family stories enough to revisit this in audiobook format. Its better reading the actual book though. The Irish accent is good but the boston accent sounds like a bad caricature and the emails don't translate well into audiobook format.

Wow! What an intense and absorbing story. I can't even imagine losing someone so close to me, but this book took you through every painful, heart wrenching moment of it. But it wasn't just about loss, it was about a madcap Irish family that was there to lighten the load. Brilliantly funny, sad and a down right good story.

It seems as I read more of Keyes books about the Walsh family, she has definitely grown as a writer. Her first few books were very "fluffy," whereas this book even though it's classified as chick-lit to me, it had more meat. The reader doesn't know why Anna is so injured until halfway through the book and what has happened to her husband. So sad!!

Re-read the entire Walsh family series in anticipation of the newest book coming out in 2022. They are a calming force in my life. When lots of other things are spiralling, I can run and listen to these and laugh and cry with them. In this one, Anna's fear and grief are quite painful at points, but it's my favourite series for a reason...

This book lures you in with a false sense of what you think happened to what actually happened. When you think you have it figured out and have guarded your heart it rips it out and stomps it into a million pieces. This book makes you question love and if the worst thing happens imaginable, could you push yourself forward?

I didn't know where this story was going. We didn't find out how Anna was hurt and what happened to Aidan till about a third of the book! Then the story started to fall in place. It's sad, it's funny, romantic and long. Her mother is quite a unique character, as well as her sisters.

Haven't read any of her other Walsh Family books. I was ready for a beach read type book and came across this one. It did have an interesting twist in the middle, but felt too long and drawn out to be an easy read page turner.

Anna Walsh feels like she is a wreck. Between her stressful job, her crazy family and even more crazy friends life is a total zoo for her. Her one great joy was meeting her husband Aidan.... until tragedy strikes. This book is both very funny and very sad but still a jolly good read.

This book was sad, and funny at the same time. Loved all the people in the book, and the emails between the sisters, and mother and daughter. I like the idea of the butterfly, and totally relate and believe.

Generally books always have kind of the same stories where as this one you think it's one of those books, but when you least expect it there is a big turning in the story that you could of actually knew from the beginning but that's what makes the writing of this book great!

I absolutely loved this book...but, it was SO sad. I was not expecting a sad story at all, and then about 100 pages in, it gets SUPER tragic, and because I was already invested, I had to get through another 300+ pages of sad stuff...be warned, this book is sad. Powerful, funny, inspiring and sad.

This is a lovely read. Yes, the genre could be considered ‘chick lit’ but the book still has some very poignant sections and made me think a lot about grief and how different people express it. Despite the subject matter it still made me chuckle at times and most of the characters I liked.

Although I was very upset where Anna found Aiden, I could see myself having the same thoughts and doing some of the things she did to get him back.Marian you never disappoint,I can't wait to read Helen's story The Walsh family #5The Mystery of Mercy Close

I picked this up in the coffee shop of our resort in Mexico over Spring Break and enjoyed it way more than I thought I would. I had no idea it was the fourth book in a series. Anna was easy to like and I laughed out loud at some of the interactions with her family.

Made it about halfway before abandoning. The plot felt like it was going nowhere fast and I wasn't intrigued enough to keep reading (I didn't realize it was a series which was an oversight on my behalf.)

A short read, very interesting about loss of a loved one. Like how Marian Keyes makes Anna main character and family and friends all become Anna's support group. Sad and funny too. Thanks Marian Keyes writing this story.

I always enjoy Marian Keyes - guilty pleasure of mine. Not the best book ever written but I do enjoy the characters and find Mariana writing style engaging, humorous and, at least when it comes to the characters emotional reactions, believable.

This book surprised me. I was scared it was going to be a sappy love-story, but it turned out to be both sad, funny and heartwarming. A very easy read, and a lovely story. Perfect for a summer holiday, when my attention span is shorter and I want something that is pure entertainment :)

As always, Marian Keys rocks! I love her books and the adventures of the sisters Walsh. I can't say this is my favorite book of her because the main topic in this story doesn't speak to me personally, but she certainly has insightful and inspiring moments.

Enjoy marian keyes books and have always loved Rachels holiday but this is alot better, very well written and extremely sad in parts but hilarious in others. Well worth a read especially if youve enjoyed her other books

One of Marian Keyes more serious novels. As many contain humor and chic-flic style genre, this one really touches well on psychological factors and a true insight into one’s thoughts and feelings going through loss and grief. A wonderful suspenseful and also twisting must read!

Excellent book. I really enjoyed the way the main protagonist's character jumps out of the page. I loved the way the issue of grief was dealt with. The humour, the pace of the story and the ending. It was the first time I read Marian Keyes but will certainly be trying more of her books.

I can't remember when I read this, but I know I did so I must mark it as such. I read a bit of the preview and what I do know is I could read all these books again and be just as entertained as the first time!

Anna has suffered through a terrible accident, and after some time recouperating with the boisterous Walsh clan in her homeland of Ireland, she is anxious to go back to New York City to find, though means including psychics, churches, and self help books, something important she has lost.

Didn't read the previous 3 Walsh books, so I found it hard to keep track of everyone. Nicely structured--kept me wondering until the first reveal. Almost too many side stories (but maybe not if you'd read the others). Good read overall.

Another great Marian Keyes book. I’m really enjoying this series. This book deals with overcoming grief, in a very emotional, but at times very funny way. I laughed, I teared up. It was all manor of emotions. I do love that Walsh family!

By far my favorite Walsh family book yet. I guessed a couple of the twists, but I don't think they were meant to be super hidden, but also loved the tone and the pace and the fun workplace and the ending. Lovely.

This was the 4th book involving the Walsh sisters which I didn’t realize but I still really enjoyed it. Will definitely go back and read the others. I love the twists and turns. It was like a quirky mystery, beach read and story of friends and lovers with an English accent. Loved it!

I love the whole Walsh family series, but having become a widow* just over a year ago, this one in particular resonated. The description of grief in the first few chapters of Part II is the best I've read. I love Anna. She's aces.(*We weren't married, so never sure whether that's the right term)

I really enjoyed this book. I listened to the audiobook at any possible moment and was a bit sad when it ended! With recently loosing a loved one I felt a connection with Anna. I really enjoyed her life story as the book went on. Would recommend.

I adore all of Keyes books. Her sense of humour is a breath of fresh air and really laugh out loud funny, but she also tackles dark and scary subjects, in this case grief and guides us gently back to the light. Long live the Walsh sisters in all their F**d up glory.

Long live the patriachate! At first I thought entertaining. Then I was confused, mhm women reduced to their looks. But after the main character was making fun policies against sexualized violence I got annoyed. So much for gender equality in the 21st century. Well done!

Once again, Marian Keyes has stolen my heart. This book definitely ranks in the top 3 books by this amazing author. The writing style and character development is what I enjoy the most. The lead female character, Anna, feels like a close friend.This book focuses on loss, grief, the meaning of love in all definitions of the word and largely on acceptance.

I was initially a bit put off by how long this book was. I did enjoy the story but it was drawn out and there was too much filler. Didn't see the point of the email bits, they were just adding unnecessary plots that didn't add to the main story, just made the book a lot longer than it needed to be.

I read this book when I was 14, a little heavy for this age, but it definitely marked my life, romance is not my favorite genre, but this book made me feel in my skin, in my soul, in my heart, all the emotions of the characters, one of the best books I've ever read, just wonderful

I wanted to know what the feeling of loss is like, how would it be painted in the eyes of others, and I can say with full confidence that the author didn’t fail at describing or painting the picture in my head. Could she have done a better job? Yes. Am I satisfied with this? Yes.

Marian Keyes books are always delightful. Funny, clever with great quirky characters and situations that are interesting and always resolve if not always the way you hope they will. This one didn’t disappoint.

Loved this book, I never read the blurbs or any reviews for books prior to reading so this definitely left me guessing and full of surprises. A story so tragic still left me in firs of laughter and balling my eyes out at the end. It’s definitely a book that’s one of a kind.

Read this out of order. Previously read Grown Ups, which I really enjoyed, surprisingly, as I didn’t think Marian Keyes was my cup of tea. When I reached the plot twist I knew it wasn’t my thing at all. Sigh! Onto something better!

This is one of those books that stays with you long after the last word. just recently re-read this again abs loved it even more. The whole story from start to finish with the heart breaking trust was just genius writing. By far my favourite of the Walsh family too.

I realized a few pages on that I had read this book quite a few years ago. I love Marian Keyes and I decided to read it again even though I have a stack of books to read for the first time. Very enjoyable, easy, fun read.

Marian Keyes is the unparalleled queen of ‘chick lit’. That last bit is in quotes because she deals with far heavier themes than the average chick lit author. Her humour is always on point and I find myself thinking the voices of her characters - this book did that too.
Marian Keyes did it again! Is Anybody Out There is now at the top of my lis of all time favorites, and here I'd been thinking nothing could beat Rachels Holiday!
This was an interesting read as I was never sure where it was headed but it was very long and I didn't connect emotionally with the characters.
4.5 ratingsA fantastic combination of laughter and tears!
Loved Marian Keyes when I was in my 20's so I was worried that this wouldn't live up to my memories, but it exceeded my expectations. Sooo funny and so sad at the same time, absolutely loved it.
I only read this book from Walsh family series and It can stand alone and this story is really beautiful and touching about Anna's journey to accept the truth and move on with her life .
I really enjoyed this, connected with all the characters really well. Perfect mix of humour and more serious emotions throughout.
An awesome book, didn't want to put it down
I found myself reading it just to finish it. I didnt enjoy it at all. Too many boring side stories. Just not my style, wasnt into it. Couldnt wait to be done.
Will surely read the other Walsh Family books. A horrible situation yet still lots of laughs - everyone's family has some crazy.
Got bored within the first few chapters as it was more like an advertisement for beauty products.
Good stuff.
My absolute favourite of the Walsh Family books. Loved it.
I expected to laugh a lot while reading this, and I did. What I hadn't expected was how much it would make me cry. I'd also forgotten how much I enjoyed the hectic adventures of the Walsh family.
This was a re-read - loved it, all over again :-)
Loved the writing style. The story was captivating as well.
I LOVED this book. Funny and heart-rending.
4 stars. This is my favorite one by far.
Boring
The first third of this book was a 5. The remainder a 2.
I like her quirky books but this was sad too.
Audiobook performed by Terry Donnelly
Mega boring
Soooooo good!
Totally enjoyable and absolutely funny. Rarely do I find books to be funny. This is my second by Keyes; I guess I'll read them all.
Classic Keyes, Walsh family again, so likeable.
I really enjoyed this book - emotional but also funny.
Quite a funny book but not always easy to follow where it was going. Sometimes a bit long winded, too.
It took me a little bit to love this book, but ultimately it was a lot of fun. I liked the characters, and it was glorious to not be able to guess all the twists.
Best one yet! Emotional yet soooo funny! Anna is a dream.
loved this book.
My new favourite book, the pacing is sensational and I love the way Marion has captured the emotional aspects
Excellent!
Pop
This book was amazing. One of my all time favourites. About half way in it made me gasp out loud and was unputdownable.
This had surprising depth to the story.

user_name: When in doubt, go to the library.
text: I've read this four or five times now and it always gets me where it hurts. I howled like a child. Bravo, Marian.
Pretty good, interesting story/s, very smooth read. A bit slow and confusing at times.
The other contender for favourite with "Rachel's Holiday".HAS ALL THE SADS!
This was Anna's story and was really good. It was sad though. And I wonder who she'll end up with? Maybe we'll find out in Helen's story.
It was weird at the beginning but the ending is sweet.
I am thoroughly enjoying The Walsh Family series.
Sweet and a little sad, but ultimately a story of human resilience
It was fine. The story completely changes after the second half reveal, and I can't say I was as interested like I was in the beginning.
Not going to lie this story moved me so much, I didn't catch on for quite a while into the story!
Beautiful
It wasn’t boring but nothing much happened. It was just nice, quite short but nice.
This is one of those books that I must have read AT LEAST six times and I never get bored of it. Such a wonderful portrayal of grief and loss with plenty of humour and good heart.
A great isolation read with lots of laugh out loud.
Starts off red hot with suspense then peters out for the second half of the book. An easy, enjoyable read. An interesting and emotional exploration of grief and loss.
First Keyes book that I've read. Really enjoyed. Very descriptive writing which is wonderful but yet can get a little unnecessary at times. Overall a great story line and really enjoyed it.
I thought I lost this book years ago since I bought it in 2007.This book is worth keeping. I enjoyed it and something I could repeatedly read.
This was not the romance novel I signed up for.
Anna is stuck in Dublin and wants to get back to New York to her husband Aidan. Sad, fun...she never lets me down! Chick lit!! Recommended.
Finally finished. This took me a while (had a lot on my plate recently getting back into the swing of things) but it was good. Another solid, classic read from Marian Keyes.
Another brilliant read !
4.5 stars. Funny in spots. Nice story
Nothing too deep, but a decent mental getaway. I reviewed it on my blog: https://wineandhistory.wordpress.com/...
Moving and beautiful and hearbreaking
Although it can be quite informal and dated to read in some places, an overall very beautiful book on grief and coming to terms with it. A plot twist too. Would highly recommend.
A very slow paced book, unlike the other books about the sisters of the Walsh family.
My first book by Marian Keyes and I absolutely love it, can't wait to dig into the rest I have. Great characters and great story line.
Enjoyable read
A slow book, enchanting, rather than quick and pacy. Glad I got to the end!
Nice light read. The side story did not make much sense so not really sure what it’s purpose was. This was my first Marian Keyes novel and I look forward to another one day.
This is a very kind and funny book about bereavement. Extremely readable and cozy. I could've done with less of the emails from Helen, however.
Really enjoyed this book and Anna's journey through the acceptance of her husband's death x
Delightful, funny, sad and beautiful.
Whimsical, funny and yes, romantic.
This was my first novel and i thoroughly regret reading it .
I think I enjoyed most of all her books
Interest look at griefSome times too predictable, but otherwise interesting look at grieving process. Heavy but not too. Nice writing style. Keeps the reader wanting more.
I really wanted to love this book. But the second part was dragging for me. The first and third part are great though, I really loved Anna.
